timeline.bodyText: This logic is not specific enough. It's possible for the update call to fail for reason unrelated to the length of the id.
timeline.author: pwinckles

replies.bodyText: so, should I check the length of the id, rather than just wrap it in an exception handler?
replies.author: robyj

replies.bodyText:
Checking the length may be reasonable, though, if we go that route, I think it would make more sense if the id length enforcement happened up in the HTTP layer.
Catching the exception here is not a problem. You just need to be more targeted about it. What is the type of exception that's thrown when the id is too long? What is the message of the exception? Are these consistent across database implementations? Using that information, you should be able to inspect the exception and only throw the id length exception when appropriate.
replies.author: pwinckles

timeline.bodyText: It is almost always a good idea to include the cause when throwing a new exception. You should do so here, unless there's a good reason not to.
timeline.author: pwinckles

replies.bodyText: you mean change the message to be more descriptive?
replies.author: robyj

replies.bodyText:
I mean include the cause in the new exception like:
throw new InvalidResourceIdentifierException("message", e);

timeline.bodyText:
Not sure I understand what lastret is doing, is this to actually return the next to last iteration of this loop? If the slashes are messing you up I think (but I could be wrong) that a single super long URI would also cause this error.
ie.
final String superLongUri = "someverrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrr...

you get the picture.
I don't think you need to have a / between each character is what I mean if that makes the loop cleaner to execute and removes the need of lastret to store the previous iteration.
timeline.author: whikloj

replies.bodyText:
Hmmm, I am using lastret to store the last string before it goes over the length required, so when it completes, lastret would contain the string that is upto the length required. Of course, I see now that the "<=" probably would return a string that is almost always less than the required length.
I used the / between the elements in the path as the original bug report script iterated a path until it was too big and the first version of the test did the same, a for loop iterated through the path. I wasn't sure if the problem was a length issue or a path "deepness" issue
